intro: Sacoila lanceolata var. paludicola, commonly known as the marsh sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland habitats. It is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, clustered flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant thrives in moist to waterlogged soils, often found in marshes, swamps, and along the edges of ponds. It plays an important ecological role by stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various invertebrates. Its botanical features make it an essential component of wetland ecosystems.
